awd_titl_txt: Polymer Adhesion at Extreme Rates and Temperatures
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polymer adhesives are one of the most pervasive applications of polymers, and their critical role in today’s technologies has only grown. The reliance of numerous technologies, from electronics to medical care to building and construction, on polymer adhesion has vastly increased the range of environments and loading conditions that these interfaces encounter. This range of environments and conditions will grow as polymer interfaces are expected to play more important roles in protective gear and in robotic devices that are specifically designed to minimize human exposure to potentially harmful extremes. Additionally, the quantity of waste that is created due to polymer adhesion and adhesives is growing at significant rates. This waste is not only polymers directly used in bonding but also the bonded materials, which are typically difficult to separate in order to be recycled or upcycled efficiently. This research project will lead to new understanding of adhesion at polymer interfaces at extreme rates of loading and temperature change. This foundation will help to meet a deficiency in the fundamental knowledge of polymer interfacial properties at extreme conditions, and we anticipate that the results will guide the development of new protocols for separating interfaces that help build a more sustainable society. Graduate and undergraduate students who participate in this project will learn a broad range of skills, including polymer synthesis and formulation, characterization methods for adhesion, mechanical and thermal properties, and the development and implementation of custom instrumentation designed to address challenges at the forefront of technology. They will also develop writing, management, mentoring, and presentation skills. Additionally, the team of researchers will launch a new K-12 outreach program geared toward under-represented minority students throughout the Western Massachusetts region to help inspire future careers in STEM. 


PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

While polymer interfacial strength has been studied classically, open questions, and seemingly contradictory results, remain unresolved in how material structure controls the deformation of interfaces loaded, mechanically and thermally, at high rates. The PI's group will combine a new experimental method, called power amplified dynamic mechanical analysis (PADMA), with model materials to provide insight and pathways for controlling polymer interfacial strength. Three model polymer systems based on poly(n-butyl acrylate), which is broadly used in many current commercial adhesives, will form the foundation of the study. Two systems will be designed with similar low strain and low strain rate properties but different large strain and large strain rate responses. This difference will be associated with the network’s crosslink junctions. These materials will provide insight into how the elasto-adhesion length scale evolves at high velocities and how this change is related to changes in the polymer network structure. The third materials system, poly(n-butyl acrylate)-co-poly(dimethylacrylamide) hydrogels with controlled volume fractions of water, will provide insight into how localized phase transitions initiated by high rate thermal changes alter interfacial separation. Specifically, the size and interconnectivity of water swollen domains will be related to changes in interfacial strength when loaded at high thermal rates. Overall, the results will contribute to the limited, yet growing, knowledge base of polymer properties at high rates, especially at interfaces. This knowledge will lead to new methods for separating polymer interfaces with decreased energy and without the need for harmful solvents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The reliance of numerous technologies, from electronics to building construction materials, on polymer adhesion has vastly increased the range of environments and loading conditions that polymer interfaces encounter. This range of environments and conditions will grow as polymer interfaces are expected to play more important roles in robotic devices and equipment for space exploration. This project has focused on measuring the forces and deformations associated with polymer hydrogels, which have large quantities of water, forming interfaces at high temperatures and mechanical loading rates. We chose these materials interfaces to allow us to understand how energy associated with phase transitions, such as liquid to vapor, can alter interface formation and separation. The lessons learned through this research project have helped us to develop new ideas for using phase transitions to assist in polymer recycling processes as well as the development of new materials for extreme environments.

Intellectual Merit:

Our research has developed new methods to measure the  forces and deformations associated with forming and separating a polymer interface at high thermal and mechanical loading rates. We have demonstrated these methods with polyacrylamide hydrogels, composed of 95% water, forming interfaces with sapphire substrates heated up to 200°C. In contrast to liquid water interacting with heated solid substrates, where water vapor barrier layers form when the solid substrate temperature approaches 200°C, our measurements show that water vapor layers form between the hydrogel surface and the sapphire when the sapphire is heated to 100°C or greater. The formation of the water vapor layer prevents interface formation, hence eliminating any forces required to separate the hydrogel from the solid. Polyacrylamide hydrogel interfaces were also studied at impact velocities to 4m/s. Preliminary analysis suggests that less energy is dissipated at higher impact velocities; however, more modeling is required to properly quantify the materials properties associated with the formed interfaces at these higher impact velocities. Measurements at these high thermal and mechanical loading rates allow us to quantify extreme behaviors of polymers and how they differ from behaviors typically quantified at lower velocities and under ambient conditions.

Broader Impacts:

This research has established a foundation for understanding how materials phase transitions can be used to alter interfacial formation and separation processes. This previously unexplored mechanism may lead to new methods for recycling, as well as developing interfaces that can sustain high thermal and mechanical loading rates. Such thermo-mechanical loading rates are commonly experienced in microelectronic devices, as well as in devices used in extreme environments, including space. In addition to the technical advances and impact of this research project, the principal investigator and students have led and participated in numerous outreach programs with elementary and high school students. At the high school level, we have participated in A Student-led Program In Research and Education (ASPIRE), which is a five weekend course for high school students to learn the fundamentals of polymer science at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. This program attracts high school students from across the state of Massachusetts. Additionally, at the elementary school level, we have worked with two first grade classrooms at Wildwood Elementary School in Amherst, MA to implement month-long lessons on bioinspired materials science and creative engineering design. These month-long lessons occurred in each June over the three year term of this project, allowing us to reach more than 90 students. Beyond outreach, this project provided key technical and professional development for three female PhD students in the field of materials science.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2024
Modified by: Alfred J Crosby
